summary: Build EchoShift, a real-time multiplayer party chat web app (MVP) for 3–6 players with anonymous usernames, room codes, lobby, role assignment, a pre-chat topic voting screen, chat gameplay with timer, a post-chat Guessing screen where only the Anchor can multi-select non-Anchor players via checkboxes and submit a guess, saving per-player correctness results to the database, then transitioning everyone to Results—no login, minimal modern responsive UI.
architectural_notes: MVP scope: no power cards yet.
Realtime backend should use Firebase or Supabase for room state + chat messages.
No authentication: players use auto-generated anonymous usernames and join via room code.
Extend the room/player data model to include a per-player 'role' field (string, default "") stored in the backend room state.

Start Game scope update: after setting exactly one player.role = "Anchor", assign every other player.role to a random value from: Overly Dramatic, Suspicious, Motivational, Alien, Villain, Emotional, Reporter, Conspiracy; persist roles; do not modify any other room/player fields.
Chat UI must display only the current player's own role (never other players' roles); if role == "Anchor" show: "You are the Anchor. Observe carefully." else show: "Your Personality: [role name]".

Add a Topic Selection phase/screen before Chat: after roles assigned, generate 3 random topics from the provided fixed list, collect one vote per player, end when all voted or after 20 seconds, choose topic with most votes, persist selected topic in room state, then transition all players to Chat; Chat UI shows selected topic at top.
Chat phase requires a room-synced 180s countdown timer that starts when Chat begins; when it expires, disable chat input and advance room phase to Guessing for all players.

Guessing phase update: after Chat timer ends, transition to a Guessing screen where only the Anchor can select any number of non-Anchor players (checkbox list) and submit; on submit, compute correctness by comparing selections vs each player's actual role, persist guess + per-player correct/incorrect results in room state/database, then advance all players to Results.

Results/Scoring rules: On Results, reveal roles (Anchor shown as "Anchor"; others show their Personality Card/role). Highlight which non-Anchor players were guessed correctly by the Anchor. Award points: Anchor gets +1 per correctly guessed non-Anchor; each non-Anchor gets +1 if the Anchor did NOT guess them. Show a summary message (e.g., "Anchor guessed X/Y correctly!" and per-player survival message) and provide a "Play Again" action that returns the room to Lobby for a new round (clean, readable UI with soft rounded cards).

existing_features.title: Create the base frontend app structure for EchoShift with these routes/screens and consistent navigation flow: Home (Create Room / Join Room), Lobby (room code + connected players + host controls), Game Chat (chat phase UI), Guessing (Anchor selects player), Results (show outcome and reveal roles/cards). All user-facing text must be in English.

Implement anonymous player identity generation on the client with auto-generated usernames in the format AdjectiveAnimalNumber (e.g., "BlueTiger42"), with no login required. Persist the generated username locally so refresh does not change it unless the user explicitly resets it.

Provide near-real-time multiplayer updates compatible with Internet Computer constraints by implementing client-side polling (via React Query refetch intervals) for room state and chat messages, instead of Firebase/Supabase realtime subscriptions.

Implement the chat phase: store chat messages per room on the backend with sender name and timestamp/order, and provide APIs to post messages and list messages. The Game Chat screen must show a scrolling message list and an input to send messages.

Implement the guessing and results flow: after the chat phase, only the Anchor can submit a single guess selecting one player as the "weird" player; then the Results screen reveals the Anchor, each player’s Personality Card (for non-Anchor players), the Anchor’s guess, and whether it was correct.

Apply a modern, clean, minimal visual theme across all screens with mobile-responsive layout, soft rounded cards, and clean typography. Choose a coherent non-blue/purple color palette and enforce consistent spacing, button styles, and surface elevations.

Add basic guardrails and UX validation: show clear errors for invalid room code, full room (more than 6 players), attempting to start with fewer than 3 players, and attempting actions not allowed for the current phase (e.g., chatting before game starts).

Update generated frontend/backend type bindings (as needed) so the frontend compiles with the updated `Player` type that now includes the `role` field, without introducing any new UI behavior or user-facing text.

On the Game Chat screen, add a role banner at the top of the screen that displays only the current player's role with the following exact copy rules: (1) If the current player's role is exactly "Anchor", show: "You are the Anchor. Observe carefully." (2) Otherwise, show: "Your Personality: [role name]" where [role name] is the current player's role value. Do not display any other role-related guidance text.
Add a new pre-chat game phase for Topic Selection that occurs after roles are assigned and before the chat phase begins.
Implement topic voting: allow each player to vote for exactly one of the 3 generated topics, persist votes in the room state, and prevent invalid votes (e.g., voting for a non-existent index/topic).

Finalize topic selection when either (a) all connected players have voted or (b) 20 seconds have elapsed since Topic Selection started: select the topic with the most votes, persist the selected topic in room state, and automatically advance the room phase to Chatting for all players.
Create a new React Topic Selection screen that displays the 3 generated topics, supports voting, and shows a visible countdown (20 seconds) until auto-finalization.
Show the selected conversation topic at the top of the Game Chat screen (above the existing role banner), using the topic stored in room state.

On the Game Chat screen, display a visible countdown timer at the top of the screen that starts automatically when the screen loads and is derived from the synchronized backend chat countdown start timestamp. The timer must show the same remaining time for all players (within the existing polling interval tolerance).

When the chat countdown reaches 0, disable the chat input on the Game Chat screen and ensure the UI cannot send new messages during/after timeout. Clients must also proactively trigger (or keep triggering) the backend auto-advance check so the room reliably transitions to Guessing even if nobody sends messages at the end of the timer.

Update frontend/backend type bindings and any necessary state/view models so the frontend compiles and can read the new chat countdown start timestamp from room state without introducing unrelated UI behavior changes.

Frontend: Replace the placeholder Guessing screen with a functional multi-select UI: show a checkbox list of all non-Anchor players; only the Anchor can interact with the checkboxes and submit; non-Anchors see a waiting state.

Frontend: Add a React Query mutation hook to submit the Anchor’s selected player IDs to the backend, handle errors with an English toast, and refresh room state so phase changes move everyone to Results.

Frontend: Update the Results screen to display the persisted guessing results (remove any placeholder text indicating guessing/scoring is not implemented) and use role == "Anchor" as the source of truth for identifying the Anchor and non-Anchor players.

Types/bindings: Update frontend backend type bindings and any RoomStateView consumption code needed so the frontend compiles and can read the new Guessing/Results fields without introducing unrelated UI behavior changes.

Update the Results screen UI to show every player with their revealed role using these exact rules: (a) if player.role is exactly "Anchor", display role label "Anchor"; (b) otherwise display the player’s Personality Card (use the player.role string as the Personality Card name).

On the Results screen, highlight which players were guessed by the Anchor and which of those guesses were correct, using the persisted roomState.guesses list as the source of truth for who was selected.

Compute and display points on the Results screen using these rules: Anchor gets 1 point for each correct guess; each non-Anchor ("Weird") player gets 1 point if the Anchor did NOT guess them. Show each player’s earned points alongside their row.

Add summary messaging on the Results screen: (a) display a top-level summary like "Anchor guessed X/Y correctly!" where X is the correct guess count and Y is the total number of non-Anchor players; (b) display per-player outcome messaging for non-Anchor players including "[PlayerName] survived without being caught!" when that player was not guessed.

Implement a "Play Again" button on the Results screen that returns the room to the Lobby for all players by resetting the room’s phase and per-round state on the backend, then letting the existing phase-based screen auto-transition move clients to Lobby.

new_feature_requests.summary: Set up base app structure and navigation for EchoShift (Home, Lobby, Game Chat, Guessing, Results) with minimal modern responsive UI
Implement realtime multiplayer rooms with join/create via room code (Firebase or Supabase)
Auto-generate anonymous usernames for players (e.g., BlueTiger42) with no login required
Lobby: show connected players and host controls to start the game
Game logic: assign 1 Anchor and Personality Cards to other players; run real-time chat phase
Guessing and results flow: Anchor guesses who had Personality Cards; show results screen

Implement backend room management in the single Motoko actor: create room with a short room code, join room by code, track connected players, track host, and expose query/update methods for the frontend to read room state and mutate it.

Implement game start and role assignment: when the host starts the game for a room with 3–6 players, the backend assigns exactly one player as Anchor and assigns a secret Personality Card to every other player. Ensure each player can only retrieve their own secret role/card, while the room state visible to everyone does not reveal secrets.
Add a 'role' string field to each player record in the room database (default empty) to support later secret role assignment
Add a new field named `role` of type `Text` to the backend `Player` record stored in each room, with a default value of the empty string (`""`) for newly created and newly joined players.
On host Start Game: randomly select one player in the room, set their player.role to "Anchor", persist to backend; do not assign any other roles/cards or change anything else

Update the backend `startGame(roomCode, hostId)` logic so that when the host starts the game it: (1) reads all players in the specified room, (2) randomly selects exactly one player from that list, (3) sets only that selected player's `role` field to the exact text `"Anchor"`, and (4) persists the updated room state. Do not assign any other roles, and do not modify any other fields (including `isAnchor`, `personalityCard`, `phase`, `hostId`, `chatMessages`, or player ordering). Keep the existing validation that only the host can start the game and that at least 3 players are required.
On Start Game after assigning one Anchor, assign each non-Anchor player a random role from the provided list and persist it (do not change Anchor or any other fields)

Update the backend `startGame(roomCode, hostId)` logic so that after one player is assigned `role = "Anchor"`, every other player in the room is assigned exactly one random role from this list and persisted in the room state: `Overly Dramatic`, `Suspicious`, `Motivational`, `Alien`, `Villain`, `Emotional`, `Reporter`, `Conspiracy`.

Chat screen: show only the current player's role at the top with conditional copy (Anchor: "You are the Anchor. Observe carefully."; otherwise: "Your Personality: [role]") and do not reveal other players' roles

Add a pre-chat Topic Selection screen: generate 3 random topics from a fixed list after role assignment, let all players vote, after all votes or 20s pick the most-voted topic, save it to the room, then auto-advance everyone to Chat; display selected topic at top of Chat screen
On game start (right after roles are assigned), generate exactly 3 random conversation topics from the provided fixed list and store them in the room state so all players see the same three options.
Chat phase: add a synced 3-minute (180s) countdown timer visible at top; starts when Chat screen loads; when it hits 0 disable chat input and auto-advance all players to Guessing

Persist a synchronized Chat phase countdown start time on the backend so all players see the same remaining time for the Chat phase (180 seconds). The countdown start time must be set when the room enters the Chatting phase after Topic Selection finalization.

Add backend logic to automatically end the Chatting phase when the 180-second countdown expires by transitioning the room phase from Chatting to Guessing, in an idempotent way that works even if multiple players trigger it around the same time.

Update Guessing flow: after chat timer ends, show Guessing screen where only the Anchor can multi-select (checkboxes) any number of non-Anchor players, submit guess, compare selections vs actual roles, persist results, then advance all players to Results
Backend: Add persistent Guessing results to room state and expose them in the room state view so the frontend can render the outcome after the Anchor submits.

Backend: Implement an update method for the Anchor to submit a Guessing selection for a room during the Guessing phase, compute correctness by comparing the submitted selections to each player's actual role, persist the computed results, and transition the room phase to Results.

Results screen enhancements: show each player’s revealed role (Anchor vs Personality Card), highlight Anchor’s correct guesses, compute/award points (Anchor +1 per correct; each non-Anchor +1 if not guessed), show summary messages, and add a 'Play Again' button returning everyone to Lobby with clean rounded-card UI

Fix backend guessing correctness counting so that submitGuesses returns a correctCount consistent with the current game rule: a guess is correct if the guessed target is a non-Anchor player (player.role != "Anchor"), regardless of Guess.guess text value.
